newsitem.title: UK: Ladbroke to close property unit, take charge. [CORRECTED 11:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Ladbroke to close property unit, take charge. [CORRECTED 11:00 GMT]

text.p: British hotels and betting company Ladbroke Group Plc said on Tuesday it would close its property division, resulting in closure costs of 52.3 million pounds ($84.4 million) and a disposal charge of 17.6 million pounds in its 1996 accounts.
Ladbroke said it sold a portfolio of about 10 commercial and residential properties to Britain's Minerva Plc for 25 million pounds.
"The closure of the property division will allow us to focus upon our core businesses of hotels and betting and gaming," Ladbroke finance director Brian Wallace said in a statement.

Ladbroke, which planned to close the unit's operations in Watford, southern England, and New York, said the net asset value of its commercial property was 373.4 million pounds ($602.7 million) at January 1, 1996 (corrects to add year.)
The properties sold to Minerva had a book value of about 34.6 million pounds and were mostly located in London and southern England.
Ladbroke said its property division also sold a stake in a Boston office building to HN Gorin Inc for $23.0 million in cash, which was about equal to book value.
The company said it expected to make a further U.S. property disposal this week for about $13 million and use the proceeds from the sales to pay down debt.
The carrying value of three remaining U.S. investment properties would be subject to a temporary writedown of 22.1 million stg, to be charged to the revaluation reserve in the group's 1996 accounts.
Ladbroke's shares slid 3.0 pence to 226 by 0832 GMT, while Minerva was up 1.5 pence to 156.
